solution.text: The frequency of occurrence of alleles of a gene or locus is supposed to remain fixed and even remain the same through generations. Hardy Weinberg principle is that allele frequencies in a population are stable and is constant from generation to generation. Total genes and their alleles (gene pool) of a population remain constant and maintain genetic equilibrium. Sum total of all the allele frequency is 1. It can also be stated as <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">q</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo></math> where p and q represent the frequency of allele A and a. Gene migration, genetic drift, mutation, genetic recombination and natural selection are factors which affect Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.
